review_title: Colleagues are the best part of the job (South Africa)
pros:
- Great Colleagues
- Most Managers have your best interests in heart, especially those who've worked there for years as they know what you're going through
- You get about a 4% increase after 6 months, 1 year, & 2 years. You also get an increase along with the entire company every year-end, depending on the company performance.
- You get added to groups where you can ask for help if you're unsure
- There are many opportunities available to you, but you can only apply after you pass probation which could take between 4-8 weeks.
- There are many competitions throughout the year with prizes like electronic devices and shopping vouchers.
- You get sent promotional items each Prime Day
- If you want extra responsibility and experience, you can simply request it.
- They offer you opportunities to study but only after 1 year and most courses deal with Tech Support and HR Management(for which they have very little space) and those are offered by colleges like Damelin and Boston City Campus
- You can contribute up to 7.5% of your salary to your Provident Fund and Amazon will match it. You can contribute more than 7.5% if you like but Amazon will not contribute anything more than the 7.5%. Momentum is responsible for this and, as a result, you will have access to TaxTim as a Momentum Member which will allow you to do your taxes for free
cons:
- Long and unreasonable shifts that you cannot change(unless you find someone to swap with). For Example, the shifts change every 6 months or so and they would send you a questionnaire to complete wherein you state your preferred shift DAYS(not hours). Most people would get their days but the hours would end up being something like 7pm-5am the next morning and the days would end up being something like Monday, Wednesday, Friday-Sunday.
- Some Managers are just inexplicable spiteful and would do the least amount of work to help you out of a bad situation. I had great managers but i had one who would just disappear for days without saying anything or answering their phone and when it came time to apply for jobs internally, he was supposed to provide recommendations and when asked, he would ignore us which led some of us to go to previous managers whom we'd not spoken to in months.
- The quiet people get taken advantage of, especially by fellow associates who get given small amounts of responsibility in their teams. I managed teams and allowed input and participation from everyone. I Allowed a free-flow of information and participation in our group to instill a sense of trust and comfortability amongst all team member, but again, this needs to occur from the top-down and in you have a bad manager, then that filters down to the group.
- The positions available to staff internally is ofter temporary which means when your contract in that role is up, you come back to being an associate.
- The company slowly reduced our capabilities from 2020-2022 and that led to more customer frustration
- You employment status is based on your performance (specifically your RAP). If you don't meet your target for 4 consecutive weeks, the OPS team contacts your manager, you receive a warning, and they put you on a performance plan for the next 12 weeks. If you don't get above the 88% performance then they dismiss you.
- Even if you've done all you can to help a customer, they can still review you negatively which will affect your overall performance and there is no way to mitigate against this, even though managers may lie and say that it does not matter. This performance also affects your future job applications as they can reject you based on your stats.
- They require you to book leave a Month in advance and if you're sick for over 7 days, they often give you a warning.
- All people that i know, who have left the company, have not received their full salary on payday and the company makes it incredible hard to get your payslips.
- Managers make up rules as and when they please and the fearmongering is on an intense level.
- The company is more interested in the customers than their employees.
- I went in thinking that Amazon South Africa was different than the US and my experience would be different than the other employees in the US because of South African Labour Laws but they really do not care. They will work you to the bone and say that you signed a contract and that you agreed to terms which you never knew about.
- You have to be outspoken and very energetic to get anywhere in the company which is unfortunate for those who are soft-spoken, but able to do the job.
- The pay at the moment is about R70 per hour. Which isn't bad, but isn't good either considering the hours worked and stress you deal with daily.
- You get verbally abused by customers and management does nothing. They recently started allowing us to block the accounts for a week but that isn't working as they come back to us more furious than before.
- Customers are not the brightest and tend to take out their frustrations on you as a result of them not being able to make use of their mental capabilities.
- The customers need to be dealt with within a certain time period which is around 10mins. If you do not speak to most of your customers for less than 10mins then you get flagged by OPS.
- You get 15mins per day, and 20mins per week, for toilet breaks. But different managers have different times. The times i mentioned were what was on our Worldwide site.
- Covid Leave used to be 14 days and now it is 10 days which they are considering lessening.
- If you want to go for a vaccine, you get half a day off to do it (4 hours). If you do it in the beginning of your shift, you have to come back and complete your shift after 4 hours, regardless of whether you have any side effects.
- If you dare take your manager to HR for not providing you the support you need, which they are required to provide to you, the manager becomes your worst enemy and General Management also backs them up to make your life hell.
- They give you training on things you aren't sure on. For example, i worked with an elderly woman who was forced to do training on Kindle and Prime Video Support of which she knew and remembered nothing. She brought this up with her manager, and i also spoke up for her when i met with General Management and they both basically said that she needs to learn how to do the job or face getting a warning. I was able to work with a previous manager and find someone who wanted to swap the training for Logistics which she was more than happy to deal with. But if I'd not found that loophole, she probably wouldn't have been working there now.

- There are more but as you can see, the con's outweigh the Pro's

job_title: Warehouse Worker in New York, NY
pros: Amazon is a company like no other in corporate America. They offer a four day work week for those working in the warehouse. Inside, there's a cafeteria, a kitchen with free coffee. There is also a good benefits package (i.e. medical, health insurance, life insurance), Paid Time Off(PTO) vacation accrued over time, tuition assistance, and swags (gifts and all thing Amazon related for the Amazon loyalists).
cons:
Amazon has some of the strictest work rules in corporate America right now. They expect their employees to give it their all ALL the time. The company expects its employees to work at lightning speed. They rate its employees with a performance system based on percentile ratings. Those who perform at of above the percentage rate could qualify for a promotion to the next level. Those who do not meet such expectations may be given the walking papers. (TRANSLATION: TERMINATION). However, they can re-apply after 90 days from the date of termination if they so choose, but then again, very unlikely.

 As stated above, Amazon expects its workers to work quickly. That's on one hand. But being this is a warehouse where there is no room for error, they take safety issues for employees extremely seriously on the other. SOMETHING HAS TO GIVE! Either they want their employees to work carefully to avoid potential workers compensation matters, or they must do away with some of the strict work rules in the company. While it's true that customer satisfaction must be met, it cannot come at the expense of risking injuries or worse. In order for Amazon to maintain its employees and to have some of its employees from leaving on its own, they must limit some of its work rules, the most important bis the performance ratings, where they are required to work at higher percentage rate.

 I am stating my case on my days employed at Amazon because there were some mixed vibes about this company. Some were true, and some were false, especially if there was a need to go to the relief station which can be done at the worksite I worked at as long as you returned to your assigned workplace immediately. For those who a considering to work for Amazon, lotsa luck and congratulations in advance on getting hired. Please be advised that working at Amazon can be Hell on Earth for some and may not be for everyone considering the long Ten(10)hours shifts and longer during peak season. I am not suggesting the reader of this comment not to apply, it is a good company to work for, you just have to deal with the work rules and expectations like every other company in America.

job_title: Software Development Engineer I in Boston, MA
pros:
This is only my second job as a software engineer out of college (the first one being only a 2 month experience), so I do not know what is the norm, nor how to compare my experience, but I will say things honestly as I think them.

Working with people has been great, I work on a small team of 5-6 people. My manager is very helpful and flexible. Asking him and other team members questions has been a good experience so far.

The working hours for me have been on average more than 8, but that was to keep up with the onboarding workload. As time passes, it feels more like 8 hours exact.

What I like is that everything is mostly very polished. Amazon does a good job with all their internal interfaces and content. This makes it easier and more enjoyable to work here compared to a previous company I worked for.

They have a very good energy and culture here. If you are a positive, optimistic, and ambitious person, this is a great company for you. They have many values and principles that are used and talked about over and over.

The work life balance is OK. Later on I will have to be on call over the weekend about once a month, but for the most part, I am able to have a balanced 8 hour work day and then switch off of work mode. Currently, our team is working 3 days in the office and 2 remotely, so this makes the work-life balance slightly better.

They seem to be very committed to diversity and inclusion. I am a hispanic hire.

The compensation and benefits are very good in my opinion. The work laptop they gave me is high-end and they let me pick between Windows and Mac. I started with Windows and switched to a Mac as it seemed most of my team used a Mac and I was having small issues with Windows.
cons:
Though it's not that I severely dislike my role, I somewhat feel like I was thrown into an arbitrary role that isn't my most desired type of work. I wish I could have had an option.

I only get around 3 weeks of paid time off/vacation during the first year, so it is a struggle to switch from being a student with many weeks off to only about 3.

Many, if not all, engineers are expected to be on call sometimes (about one week and weekend a month I believe), so this lowers the work-life balance a little bit.

I wish I had the freedom to work remotely year-round (currently they do allow employees to work remotely for 4 weeks per year, with approval). Also, working remotely is mostly restricted to within the country, and I wish that I was able to work anywhere.

One disadvantage for me is that my team operates off of EST, so a 9 AM start time for them means an 8 AM start time for me while working from home (I live in Texas). This is temporary however. So pick your office location carefully if they offer you options and if you plan to work from home at all.

- Turnover. People join and leave constantly and quickly to move up the ladder or to other teams within Amazon or AWS which can throw things into disarray and create slack that needs to be tightened up. 
- Constant new rules/policies/procedures/tools. Nothing can ever settle because everyone is always moving at 1000mph. 
- Meetings. Constant unnecessary team meetings and project meetings and follow-up meetings and status update meetings.

review_title: Not as great as I thought
pros:
I was happy to work for Amazon and generally enjoyed my time there. However, Amazon see's corporate and FC workers as replaceable and inconsequential parts in its Borg like spaceship. Amazon banks on employees separating after two years, and won't blink an eye when someone leaves. Retention measures were non-existent as of 7 months ago, but it sounds like some things may have changed in terms of retention and compensation. The fact that it took Amazon the entire pandemic to figure it out has made me lose a lot of faith and trust in the company.
 
If you take a job with Amazon: speak up for yourself, network (a lot), take notes on team and manager expectations ('Start, Stop, Continue'), immediately start tracking your accomplishments in detail and plan an exit strategy before your two years of servitude is up.

Pros:
- Inclusive culture
- Welcoming
- Work with very smart, professional, down to earth people
- Autonomy
- Work flexibility
- Clearly defined onboarding path
- Great pay (to start)
- Great benefits
- Structured review cycle
cons:
Cons:
- (Typically) no work-life balance/culture
- People Managers that don't have people skills
- People Managers that play favorites and/or don't actually help to professionally develop their team 
- People Managers that don't actually have time to manage people
- Constant re-orgs
- A lot of smoke blowing
- A lot of opportunities to take on more work and responsibilities with (usually) no recognition
- Very difficult to promo to a higher level
- Second year bonus drop off
- Horrible annual review system that allows co-workers, prior and temporary managers to trash you without actually following the SMART goal criteria
- No process in place to appeal what's said or determined in the annual reviews
- Annual review pay increases (1%-3% annually) do not make up for lost income when 2nd year bonus drops
- The only time you'll have to modify your pay/contract is when you're first hired (i.e. does not occur during lateral or higher work title moves)
- Promotions (if you're lucky enough to get one) typically only give you a 3%-5% annual increase
- The promo process usually takes 6-8 months to complete, and that's IF you're approved to pursue one
- The "Total Compensation Package" is a sham 
- By year 2, you'll need to promo to a higher level, then apply for a different position (likely with another team) to then renegotiate your contract/pay
- Stock options vest over a 5 year period. If Amazon doesn't think you'll be there after year 2, how much are you really getting? (Year 1; vesting ~5%, year 2; vesting ~%15...)
- Stock options will not make up for lost income. Understand what the share is worth right now (don't hedge on double-digit growth as Amazon wants you to think) and how much your tax obligation/capital gains tax will be. In other words, your stocks aren't worth quite as much as you think.

pros:
I recently started working at AWS, and so far, I can tell I was brought into a great team. If you are reading reviews online about AWS or positions like mine, you may be torn between reviews like this one and others where the cons list is infinite. Where other current or former Amazonians are talking about their toxic workplaces - but this varies per site. Some sites focus on metrics and how many tickets you can resolve in a week, or even in a day; but that is not true for all sites or all teams. The management for my team has emphasized since my first day that we want to provide quality over quantity. We want to be customer obsessed and actually resolve the problem of the customer without rushing and cutting corners. I am more than happy with this position and the learning opportunity AWS has provided to me. However, this job is not for everyone, and you have to stay on your toes to move up and be successful (this is something that I am learning as I spend more time here). You need to put in the work, deep dive, learn to be curious, and also take ownership for mistakes you may commit along the way - and that is, unsurprisingly, not something all people are up for. 

I think this job is great so far, and the environment is very healthy. Workplace culture is great, and all the techs are very good at what they do and great at teaching and passing on their knowledge. Benefits are amazing at this company, and they provide an immense amount of support, especially if you get COVID and need to quarantine for a few days (speaking from personal experience).
cons:
The only con I would have for my current position is the "not so typical" work week schedule. I work 10 hrs. shifts, 4 days a week, during the front half of the week. This means my shift goes from Sun. to Wed., from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m.

This is not that bad once you become accustomed to it, but working on Sundays can be a little disappointing when you're used to working from Mon. to Fri. and having the weekends off. They don’t like the word micro manage however; God forbid you have an idea that doesn’t conform to how they can capitalise (as mentioned above) on the problem or solution. Suddenly LP (Leadership principles) are weaponised for self serving purposes and at times completely twisted from original meaning.
Almost Everyone peers/management operate in the Are right a lot LP space. Since they are right a lot why bother seek diverse perspectives? So the title and, 1st sentence of the LP is all that matters. If folks are right a lot there is no room to learn anything. So you will see folks are incorrect but won’t listen so we move forward that way.

American based culture: 
Ordinarily this isn’t a bad thing if they are inclusive of other cultures and understand that those who are not American need a moment to catch on. Then there is the Amazon peculiar culture which is a derivative of the American culture that isn’t a problem if time is taken to understand those that are non American or have previous Amazon experience need a moment to understand what is going on.
Bad behaviour is justified as culture, rude tones, throwing people under the bus, excluding others, etc. honestly we should seek to grow and do better not stay where we are. What was okay 10 years ago isn’t necessarily okay now! 

Long hours: 
In the UK they get you to waive the 48 max hours a week clause in contract after 3 months you can get HR to amend and reinstate; however that will look as though you are lazy. Be prepared to work long hours all the time. ~60 a week and if including weekends possibly even more. Then you may be told you don’t know how to time
Manage when you ask management to look into and it’s an opportunity for them to micro manage. Yet the work load does not decrease. 

Race:
It’s very black and white! So you are judged already based on the colour of your skin; certain bias is associated with who you are, what you can do, how smart or weak you are. It is truly appalling! 

My ultimate aim is to leave as I am now sick mentally and physically due to this place. Avoid if you can but remember this is my experience, I wish I had listened to the reviews I read and avoided but we live and learn!
